linkTarget.anchoringText: These problems have been mitigated by the introduction of the so-called Advanced Well Completion Technology such as annular flow isolation (e.g. Swell Packers) and downhole flow control (e.g. Inflow control devices (ICDs), interval control devices (ICVs) and autonomous flow control devices (AFCDs) (Fig. 1). Well monitoring capabilities are also generally more advanced with in-well, permanent sensors, including multiple pressure and temperature sensors ( Da Silva et al., 2012).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Example Intelligent Well components (Da Silva et al., 2012)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example Intelligent Well components (Da Silva et al., 2012)

linkTarget.bib:
Da Silva et al., (2012)
M. F. Da Silva, , K. M. Muradov and D. R. Davies
(2012). Review, Analysis and Comparison of Intelligent Well Monitoring Systems, Society of Petroleum Engineers, http://dx.doi.org/10.2118/150195-MS

linkTarget.anchoringText: Before analyzing the rela well data, the effect of an ICD completion on PTA was analysed with an integrated, transient, dynamic, coupled wellbore-reservoir model built with a commercial simulator. This was necessary to provide insight on how to approach the real data in the context of this problem. The wellbore model (Fig. 2) consists of a three zone, horizontal intelligent well with both nozzle type ICDs and ICVs for production control and monitoring. The flow path in this completion is designed such that the reservoir fluid first goes to the annulus through ICDs and then ICVs are used to connect the annulus to the tubing.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Wellbore Schematic

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wellbore Schematic

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir simulation model was built with 30*30*11 gridblocks and local grid refinement (LGR) ensured proper representation of the pressure changes near the wellbore (Fig. 3). The well is placed in the middle of a homogenous reservoir with no flow boundaries and the five connections per zone is designed to link the reservoir to wellbore. Both fixed flow rate and tubing head pressure were used for production control. The well test schedule is required the zones to be tested sequentially by closing the ICVs across each zone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Reservoir Model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir Model

linkTarget.anchoringText: Five distinct flow regimes (Fig.4) can be traditionally expected to be identified from the derivative plot (pʹ = dpwf / dlnt) during conventional PTA of horizontal well data, subject to the reservoir boundaries configuration. Each flow regime provides specific information about the reservoir and/or the completion. For example, the damage skin (Sd) and the product of the permeability in x and z direction (Kx.Kz) can be estimated from the early radial flow regime using for instance Eqn. 2, 3 and 4 (John Lee et al., 2003).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Possible flow regimes for horizontal wells on log-log plot (John Lee 2003)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Possible flow regimes for horizontal wells on log-log plot (John Lee 2003)

linkTarget.bib:
John Lee and Spivey, (2003)
J. R. John Lee , John Spivey
(2003). “Pressure Transeint Testing.” volume 9.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The distance between stabilised value in the derivative and the pressure plots is related to the skin while the stablisation level value in the derivative plot is inversely proportional to permeability (Fig. 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Skin and Permeability in a log-log plot

formatted-caption.caption-text: Skin and Permeability in a log-log plot

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 6 illustrates the influence of the pressure drop imposed by ICDs of different effective diameters (or strength) per zone for the same production rate while Fig. 7 illustrates the resulting pressure trend for both the draw down and build-up period at the well’s toe section as measured both upstream and downstream of the ICD. The presence of the ICD is only observed in the drawdown period i.e. the pressure build-up data measured upstream of the ICD overlays the downstream measured data since there is zero flow rate in this period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Pressure Drop across an ICD vs. effective Diameter

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure Drop across an ICD vs. effective Diameter

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 6 illustrates the influence of the pressure drop imposed by ICDs of different effective diameters (or strength) per zone for the same production rate while Fig. 7 illustrates the resulting pressure trend for both the draw down and build-up period at the well’s toe section as measured both upstream and downstream of the ICD. The presence of the ICD is only observed in the drawdown period i.e. the pressure build-up data measured upstream of the ICD overlays the downstream measured data since there is zero flow rate in this period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Drawdown and Build-Up Pressure Profiles for a ½ in. ICD completion (constant surface rate)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Drawdown and Build-Up Pressure Profiles for a ½ in. ICD completion (constant surface rate)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 8 is the log-log PTA plot for the toe zone of a completed well either with a Standalone Screen (SAS) or ½ in. or 1.0 in. diameter ICD. PTA is limited to the early radial flow regime in x-z plane and the evaluation of the (kx.kz) parameter. Straight line analysis estimated the Table 2 values of permeability and skin by use of Eqn.3 and 4 derived for conventional PTA. The smaller diameter ICD dramatically increased the estimated skin while retaining the same permeability product for all the three cases (Fig. 8). This skin represents both the damage zone and ICD pressure losses, and can no longer be used to estimate quality of the damage zone alon. On the other hand, the derivative plots (inversely proportional to permeability) are identical.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Log-log PTA plot for the Draw-Down Period (Constant rate)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log PTA plot for the Draw-Down Period (Constant rate)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The smaller diameter ICD dramatically increased the estimated skin while retaining the same permeability product for all the three cases (Fig. 8). This skin represents both the damage zone and ICD pressure losses, and can no longer be used to estimate quality of the damage zone alon. On the other hand, the derivative plots (inversely proportional to permeability) are identical. The zonal flow rates (Fig. 9) and the ICD pressure drops (Fig. 10) were almost constant after a short transient time. (Fig. 9 also shows that installing ICD increases the flow rate of toe zone which results in more uniform inflow along the complation –the major objective of installing ICD completion at first place).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Zonal Flow Rate vs. Time (constant rate)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Zonal Flow Rate vs. Time (constant rate)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The smaller diameter ICD dramatically increased the estimated skin while retaining the same permeability product for all the three cases (Fig. 8). This skin represents both the damage zone and ICD pressure losses, and can no longer be used to estimate quality of the damage zone alon. On the other hand, the derivative plots (inversely proportional to permeability) are identical. The zonal flow rates (Fig. 9) and the ICD pressure drops (Fig. 10) were almost constant after a short transient time. (Fig. 9 also shows that installing ICD increases the flow rate of toe zone which results in more uniform inflow along the complation –the major objective of installing ICD completion at first place).

image-wrap.label: Figure10
image-wrap.caption: ICD Pressure Drop vs. Time (constant rate)

formatted-caption.caption-text: ICD Pressure Drop vs. Time (constant rate)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 11 summarises the PTA of the pressure build-up period. The pressure plots are distinct with the derivative curves of them being nearly identical. Our simulation assumed perfect downhole shut-in, hence the flow rate is a time independent parameter (i.e. sandface flow rate stops or starts nearly instantenously subject to the inter-zone interference), even though the plots for all three completions start at different pressure value due to their differing ICD pressure drops.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Log-log PTA plot of the Build-Up Pressure vs. Time (constant rate)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log PTA plot of the Build-Up Pressure vs. Time (constant rate)

linkTarget.anchoringText: To induce larger flow rate variation, for the second case the well is assumed to be controlled with constant well head pressure. Flow rate is now a time dependent parameter and the pressures drop across the ICD is both time and rate dependent during PTA (see Fig.12 and 13). The rate-normalized pressure and the pressure derivatives (Fig.14) are all different; hence the estimated permeability and skin factor for the ICD completions will be incorrect (Table 3). By contrast, the pressure build-up derivative plots (Fig.15) are not affected by ICD pressure drop (since the flow rate, and so the pressure loss across the ICDs, eventually disappears), though the pressure change curves are also distinct, resulting in an overestimated skin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Zonal Flow Rate vs. Time (constant WHP)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Zonal Flow Rate vs. Time (constant WHP)

linkTarget.anchoringText: To induce larger flow rate variation, for the second case the well is assumed to be controlled with constant well head pressure. Flow rate is now a time dependent parameter and the pressures drop across the ICD is both time and rate dependent during PTA (see Fig.12 and 13). The rate-normalized pressure and the pressure derivatives (Fig.14) are all different; hence the estimated permeability and skin factor for the ICD completions will be incorrect (Table 3). By contrast, the pressure build-up derivative plots (Fig.15) are not affected by ICD pressure drop (since the flow rate, and so the pressure loss across the ICDs, eventually disappears), though the pressure change curves are also distinct, resulting in an overestimated skin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: ICD Pressure Drop vs. Time (constant WHP)

formatted-caption.caption-text: ICD Pressure Drop vs. Time (constant WHP)

Flow rate is now a time dependent parameter and the pressures drop across the ICD is both time and rate dependent during PTA (see Fig.12 and 13). The rate-normalized pressure and the pressure derivatives (Fig.14) are all different; hence the estimated permeability and skin factor for the ICD completions will be incorrect (Table 3). By contrast, the pressure build-up derivative plots (Fig.15) are not affected by ICD pressure drop (since the flow rate, and so the pressure loss across the ICDs, eventually disappears), though the pressure change curves are also distinct, resulting in an overestimated skin.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To induce larger flow rate variation, for the second case the well is assumed to be controlled with constant well head pressure. Flow rate is now a time dependent parameter and the pressures drop across the ICD is both time and rate dependent during PTA (see Fig.12 and 13). The rate-normalized pressure and the pressure derivatives (Fig.14) are all different; hence the estimated permeability and skin factor for the ICD completions will be incorrect (Table 3). By contrast, the pressure build-up derivative plots (Fig.15) are not affected by ICD pressure drop (since the flow rate, and so the pressure loss across the ICDs, eventually disappears), though the pressure change curves are also distinct, resulting in an overestimated skin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Log-log PTA plot of Build-Up Pressure vs. Time (Constant WHP)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log PTA plot of Build-Up Pressure vs. Time (Constant WHP)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results for a uniform and variable ICD strength along the wellbore, for constant rate production, are shown in Fig.16 and 17. This comparison shows that for the uniform ICD strength distributed along the wellbore, the effect of ICDs is still mainly on the pressure plot; but for variable ICD strength, both pressure and pressure derivative plots are distorted. The conventional interpretation methods for both uniform and variable ICD strength cases are similarly affected for variable flow rate modelled by constant tubing head pressure, if analyzing pressure measured at the heel, although the results are not shown here.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Uniform ICD along the wellbore

formatted-caption.caption-text: Uniform ICD along the wellbore

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results for a uniform and variable ICD strength along the wellbore, for constant rate production, are shown in Fig.16 and 17. This comparison shows that for the uniform ICD strength distributed along the wellbore, the effect of ICDs is still mainly on the pressure plot; but for variable ICD strength, both pressure and pressure derivative plots are distorted. The conventional interpretation methods for both uniform and variable ICD strength cases are similarly affected for variable flow rate modelled by constant tubing head pressure, if analyzing pressure measured at the heel, although the results are not shown here.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Variable ICD along the wellbore

formatted-caption.caption-text: Variable ICD along the wellbore

linkTarget.anchoringText: A workflow to decompose the total skin for ICD completed wells based on the mentioned formulae is summaried in Fig. 18. Two different options are presented where the second approach is recommended if commercial well test software is available and the first one is preferred when the reservoir, well and completion models are not very complex and reliable correlations for different skin are available.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Workflow to decompose the Total Skin for ICD completed wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Workflow to decompose the Total Skin for ICD completed wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Golden Eagle Area Development, located in the UKCS approximately 100 km North East of Aberdeen, comprises the Golden Eagle, Peregrine and Solitaire fields (Fig. 19). The three fields are produced via a combination of platform and subsea wells from three drill centres: a wellhead platform adjacent to the central processing platform (Golden Eagle wells), a Southern manifold subsea drill centre (Peregrine wells) and a Northern manifold subsea drill centre (Golden Eagle and Solitaire wells). Production commenced in October 2014 and water injection began shortly thereafter.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Golden Eagle Area Development Map

formatted-caption.caption-text: Golden Eagle Area Development Map

linkTarget.anchoringText: The development strategy for the Punt is also via waterflood, but use a pattern flood along the length of the Punt channel. This is because the Punt sands are fully oil bearing across most of the Golden Eagle accumulation with sand pinchout to the east and west. The structure only dips below the free water level in the extreme north and southeast of the field. Punt producers are located towards the Punt sand highs, with injectors generally in the structural lows. Producers and injectors alternate along the axis of the Punt fairway with a higher density of producers towards the crest of the structure near the 20/1-8 appraisal well, where the greatest thickness of net pay is encountered (Fig. 20).

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Cross Section through Central Golden Eagle Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross Section through Central Golden Eagle Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 21 is a schematic diagramme of a three zone, production well. The pressure and temperature sensors are located immediately above the ICV for each zone. The uppermost gauge mandrel immediately below the production packer is a combined flowmeter and pressure/temperature sensor. A three optical-fibre cable bundle is clamped to the inner production string. It covers the three reservoir intervals; the Upper Punt, Lower Punt and Burns in this case. Distributed temperature sensing is provided by one of the fibres for inferring the water injection profile during shut-in warmbacks. Unfortunately the resolution has proved to be insufficient for production inflow profiling.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Golden Eagle 3 Zone Sandface Completion Schematic

formatted-caption.caption-text: Golden Eagle 3 Zone Sandface Completion Schematic

linkTarget.anchoringText: Well A is a three zone, production well with a deviation of 60°. The flow rate and annulus pressure for the upper zone, Zone 1, is shown in Fig. 22. There are three main pressure build-ups. PBU1, the longest, was conducted immediately after the initial clean-up. The total rate is measured by a multiphase, flow meter with the zonal rate being allocated by PDGs that directly measure the pressure in the annulus and tubing.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Zone 1 Pressure andFlow Rate History

formatted-caption.caption-text: Zone 1 Pressure andFlow Rate History

linkTarget.anchoringText: The three pressure build-up periods are overlaid in the log-log plot (Fig. 23). The the pressure and derivative plots are almost identical, hence there are no significant changes in either the reservoir or near wellbore throughout the study period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Log-log PTA plot for Well A, Zone-1, PBU data (from Fig. 22)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log PTA plot for Well A, Zone-1, PBU data (from Fig. 22)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The second data set is provided by well B, a three zone IW of similar completion design to well A. Fig. 24 presents the PTA of zone 3 for two PBU periods in Febraury and April which conducted after a production period with two different flow rate. There is small observable change in skin between the two PBUs but the quality of data is not as good as the Zone 1 in well A and the duration of the PBUs are even relatively short. This can affect the interpretation results and hence reduce the confidence interval. Nevertheless, the proposed workflow was followed for the longer and better quality data set in February resulting in ICD pressure drop of 0.63 psia which is equivalent to a ICD skin of 0.1, and therefore based on Eqn.12 the Formation damage skin of 0.34 (Table 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Log-Log PTA plot for Well B, Zone 3, PBU data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-Log PTA plot for Well B, Zone 3, PBU data

linkTarget.anchoringText: The level of stabilisation, which represents the permeability, should remain constant, while the separation between the level of the stabilization and pressure plots, indicative of the total skin, may change over time. Inconsistency in pressure plots can be due to ICD plugging/ erosion. For example, Fig. 25 shows three idealized cases where the effect of ICD plugging and erosion is compared. In this figure it is assumed that there are 30 nozzles per ICD joint, similar to the presented real field data. Increasing the pressure draw down, shifting pressure plot upward, or decreasing, shifting down ward, is the result of ICD plugging and erosion respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Log-log Pressure and Derivative Plots for ICD Performance Monitoring

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log Pressure and Derivative Plots for ICD Performance Monitoring
